015package com.google.common.cache;
016
017import static com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkArgument;
018import static com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkNotNull;
019import static com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkState;
020
021import com.google.common.annotations.GwtCompatible;
022import com.google.common.annotations.GwtIncompatible;
023import com.google.common.base.Ascii;
024import com.google.common.base.Equivalence;
025import com.google.common.base.MoreObjects;
026import com.google.common.base.Supplier;
027import com.google.common.base.Suppliers;
028import com.google.common.base.Ticker;
029import com.google.common.cache.AbstractCache.SimpleStatsCounter;
030import com.google.common.cache.AbstractCache.StatsCounter;
031import com.google.common.cache.LocalCache.Strength;
032import com.google.errorprone.annotations.CheckReturnValue;
033import java.lang.ref.SoftReference;
034import java.lang.ref.WeakReference;
035import java.util.ConcurrentModificationException;
036import java.util.IdentityHashMap;
037import java.util.Map;
038import java.util.concurrent.ConcurrentHashMap;
039import java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit;
040import java.util.logging.Level;
041import java.util.logging.Logger;
042import org.checkerframework.checker.nullness.compatqual.NullableDecl;
043
044/**
045 * A builder of {@link LoadingCache} and {@link Cache} instances.
046 *
047 * <h2>Prefer <a href="https://github.com/ben-manes/caffeine/wiki">Caffeine</a> over {@code
048 * common.cache}</h2>
049 *
050 * <p>The successor to {@code common.cache} is <a
051 * href="https://github.com/ben-manes/caffeine/wiki">Caffeine</a>. Its API is designed to make it a
052 * nearly drop-in replacement (though it require Java 8 APIs). (Its equivalent to {@code
053 * CacheBuilder} is its <a
054 * href="https://www.javadoc.io/doc/com.github.ben-manes.caffeine/caffeine/latest/com/github/benmanes/caffeine/cache/Caffeine.html">{@code
055 * Caffeine}</a> class.) It offers better performance, more features (including asynchronous
056 * loading), and fewer <a
057 * href="https://github.com/google/guava/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3Apackage%3Dcache+label%3Atype%3Ddefect">bugs</a>.
058 *
059 * <h2>More on {@code CacheBuilder}</h2>
060 *
061 * {@code CacheBuilder} builds caches with any combination of the following features:
062 *
063 * <ul>
064 *   <li>automatic loading of entries into the cache
065 *   <li>least-recently-used eviction when a maximum size is exceeded
066 *   <li>time-based expiration of entries, measured since last access or last write
067 *   <li>keys automatically wrapped in {@code WeakReference}
068 *   <li>values automatically wrapped in {@code WeakReference} or {@code SoftReference}
069 *   <li>notification of evicted (or otherwise removed) entries
070 *   <li>accumulation of cache access statistics
071 * </ul>
072 *
073 * <p>These features are all optional; caches can be created using all or none of them. By default
074 * cache instances created by {@code CacheBuilder} will not perform any type of eviction.
075 *
076 * <p>Usage example:
077 *
078 * <pre>{@code
079 * LoadingCache<Key, Graph> graphs = CacheBuilder.newBuilder()
080 *     .maximumSize(10000)
081 *     .expireAfterWrite(10, TimeUnit.MINUTES)
082 *     .removalListener(MY_LISTENER)
083 *     .build(
084 *         new CacheLoader<Key, Graph>() {
085 *           public Graph load(Key key) throws AnyException {
086 *             return createExpensiveGraph(key);
087 *           }
088 *         });
089 * }</pre>
090 *
091 * <p>Or equivalently,
092 *
093 * <pre>{@code
094 * // In real life this would come from a command-line flag or config file
095 * String spec = "maximumSize=10000,expireAfterWrite=10m";
096 *
097 * LoadingCache<Key, Graph> graphs = CacheBuilder.from(spec)
098 *     .removalListener(MY_LISTENER)
099 *     .build(
100 *         new CacheLoader<Key, Graph>() {
101 *           public Graph load(Key key) throws AnyException {
102 *             return createExpensiveGraph(key);
103 *           }
104 *         });
105 * }</pre>
106 *
107 * <p>The returned cache is implemented as a hash table with similar performance characteristics to
108 * {@link ConcurrentHashMap}. It implements all optional operations of the {@link LoadingCache} and
109 * {@link Cache} interfaces. The {@code asMap} view (and its collection views) have <i>weakly
110 * consistent iterators</i>. This means that they are safe for concurrent use, but if other threads
111 * modify the cache after the iterator is created, it is undefined which of these changes, if any,
112 * are reflected in that iterator. These iterators never throw {@link
113 * ConcurrentModificationException}.
114 *
115 * <p><b>Note:</b> by default, the returned cache uses equality comparisons (the {@link
116 * Object#equals equals} method) to determine equality for keys or values. However, if {@link
117 * #weakKeys} was specified, the cache uses identity ({@code ==}) comparisons instead for keys.
118 * Likewise, if {@link #weakValues} or {@link #softValues} was specified, the cache uses identity
119 * comparisons for values.
120 *
121 * <p>Entries are automatically evicted from the cache when any of {@linkplain #maximumSize(long)
122 * maximumSize}, {@linkplain #maximumWeight(long) maximumWeight}, {@linkplain #expireAfterWrite
123 * expireAfterWrite}, {@linkplain #expireAfterAccess expireAfterAccess}, {@linkplain #weakKeys
124 * weakKeys}, {@linkplain #weakValues weakValues}, or {@linkplain #softValues softValues} are
125 * requested.
126 *
127 * <p>If {@linkplain #maximumSize(long) maximumSize} or {@linkplain #maximumWeight(long)
128 * maximumWeight} is requested entries may be evicted on each cache modification.
129 *
130 * <p>If {@linkplain #expireAfterWrite expireAfterWrite} or {@linkplain #expireAfterAccess
131 * expireAfterAccess} is requested entries may be evicted on each cache modification, on occasional
132 * cache accesses, or on calls to {@link Cache#cleanUp}. Expired entries may be counted by {@link
133 * Cache#size}, but will never be visible to read or write operations.
134 *
135 * <p>If {@linkplain #weakKeys weakKeys}, {@linkplain #weakValues weakValues}, or {@linkplain
136 * #softValues softValues} are requested, it is possible for a key or value present in the cache to
137 * be reclaimed by the garbage collector. Entries with reclaimed keys or values may be removed from
138 * the cache on each cache modification, on occasional cache accesses, or on calls to {@link
139 * Cache#cleanUp}; such entries may be counted in {@link Cache#size}, but will never be visible to
140 * read or write operations.
141 *
142 * <p>Certain cache configurations will result in the accrual of periodic maintenance tasks which
143 * will be performed during write operations, or during occasional read operations in the absence of
144 * writes. The {@link Cache#cleanUp} method of the returned cache will also perform maintenance, but
145 * calling it should not be necessary with a high throughput cache. Only caches built with
146 * {@linkplain #removalListener removalListener}, {@linkplain #expireAfterWrite expireAfterWrite},
147 * {@linkplain #expireAfterAccess expireAfterAccess}, {@linkplain #weakKeys weakKeys}, {@linkplain
148 * #weakValues weakValues}, or {@linkplain #softValues softValues} perform periodic maintenance.
149 *
150 * <p>The caches produced by {@code CacheBuilder} are serializable, and the deserialized caches
151 * retain all the configuration properties of the original cache. Note that the serialized form does
152 * <i>not</i> include cache contents, but only configuration.
153 *
154 * <p>See the Guava User Guide article on <a
155 * href="https://github.com/google/guava/wiki/CachesExplained">caching</a> for a higher-level
156 * explanation.
157 *
158 * @param <K> the most general key type this builder will be able to create caches for. This is
159 *     normally {@code Object} unless it is constrained by using a method like {@code
160 *     #removalListener}
161 * @param <V> the most general value type this builder will be able to create caches for. This is
162 *     normally {@code Object} unless it is constrained by using a method like {@code
163 *     #removalListener}
164 * @author Charles Fry
165 * @author Kevin Bourrillion
166 * @since 10.0
167 */
168@GwtCompatible(emulated = true)
169public final class CacheBuilder<K, V> {
170  private static final int DEFAULT_INITIAL_CAPACITY = 16;
171  private static final int DEFAULT_CONCURRENCY_LEVEL = 4;
172
173  @SuppressWarnings("GoodTime") // should be a java.time.Duration
174  private static final int DEFAULT_EXPIRATION_NANOS = 0;
175
176  @SuppressWarnings("GoodTime") // should be a java.time.Duration
177  private static final int DEFAULT_REFRESH_NANOS = 0;
178
179  static final Supplier<? extends StatsCounter> NULL_STATS_COUNTER =
180      Suppliers.ofInstance(
181          new StatsCounter() {
182            @Override
183            public void recordHits(int count) {}
184
185            @Override
186            public void recordMisses(int count) {}
187
188            @SuppressWarnings("GoodTime") // b/122668874
189            @Override
190            public void recordLoadSuccess(long loadTime) {}
191
192            @SuppressWarnings("GoodTime") // b/122668874
193            @Override
194            public void recordLoadException(long loadTime) {}
195
196            @Override
197            public void recordEviction() {}
198
199            @Override
200            public CacheStats snapshot() {
201              return EMPTY_STATS;
202            }
203          });
204  static final CacheStats EMPTY_STATS = new CacheStats(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0);
205
206  static final Supplier<StatsCounter> CACHE_STATS_COUNTER =
207      new Supplier<StatsCounter>() {
208        @Override
209        public StatsCounter get() {
210          return new SimpleStatsCounter();
211        }
212      };
213
214  enum NullListener implements RemovalListener<Object, Object> {
215    INSTANCE;
216
217    @Override
218    public void onRemoval(RemovalNotification<Object, Object> notification) {}
219  }
220
221  enum OneWeigher implements Weigher<Object, Object> {
222    INSTANCE;
223
224    @Override
225    public int weigh(Object key, Object value) {
226      return 1;
227    }
228  }
229
230  static final Ticker NULL_TICKER =
231      new Ticker() {
232        @Override
233        public long read() {
234          return 0;
235        }
236      };
237
238  private static final Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(CacheBuilder.class.getName());
239
240  static final int UNSET_INT = -1;
241
242  boolean strictParsing = true;
243
244  int initialCapacity = UNSET_INT;
245  int concurrencyLevel = UNSET_INT;
246  long maximumSize = UNSET_INT;
247  long maximumWeight = UNSET_INT;
248  @NullableDecl Weigher<? super K, ? super V> weigher;
249
250  @NullableDecl Strength keyStrength;
251  @NullableDecl Strength valueStrength;
252
253  @SuppressWarnings("GoodTime") // should be a java.time.Duration
254  long expireAfterWriteNanos = UNSET_INT;
255
256  @SuppressWarnings("GoodTime") // should be a java.time.Duration
257  long expireAfterAccessNanos = UNSET_INT;
258
259  @SuppressWarnings("GoodTime") // should be a java.time.Duration
260  long refreshNanos = UNSET_INT;
261
262  @NullableDecl Equivalence<Object> keyEquivalence;
263  @NullableDecl Equivalence<Object> valueEquivalence;
264
265  @NullableDecl RemovalListener<? super K, ? super V> removalListener;
266  @NullableDecl Ticker ticker;
267
268  Supplier<? extends StatsCounter> statsCounterSupplier = NULL_STATS_COUNTER;
269
270  private CacheBuilder() {}
271
272  /**
273   * Constructs a new {@code CacheBuilder} instance with default settings, including strong keys,
274   * strong values, and no automatic eviction of any kind.
275   *
276   * <p>Note that while this return type is {@code CacheBuilder<Object, Object>}, type parameters on
277   * the {@link #build} methods allow you to create a cache of any key and value type desired.
278   */
279  @CheckReturnValue
280  public static CacheBuilder<Object, Object> newBuilder() {
281    return new CacheBuilder<>();
282  }
283
284  /**
285   * Constructs a new {@code CacheBuilder} instance with the settings specified in {@code spec}.
286   *
287   * @since 12.0
288   */
289  @GwtIncompatible // To be supported
290  @CheckReturnValue
291  public static CacheBuilder<Object, Object> from(CacheBuilderSpec spec) {
292    return spec.toCacheBuilder().lenientParsing();
293  }
294
295  /**
296   * Constructs a new {@code CacheBuilder} instance with the settings specified in {@code spec}.
297   * This is especially useful for command-line configuration of a {@code CacheBuilder}.
298   *
299   * @param spec a String in the format specified by {@link CacheBuilderSpec}
300   * @since 12.0
301   */
302  @GwtIncompatible // To be supported
303  @CheckReturnValue
304  public static CacheBuilder<Object, Object> from(String spec) {
305    return from(CacheBuilderSpec.parse(spec));
306  }
307
308  /**
309   * Enables lenient parsing. Useful for tests and spec parsing.
310   *
311   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
312   */
313  @GwtIncompatible // To be supported
314  CacheBuilder<K, V> lenientParsing() {
315    strictParsing = false;
316    return this;
317  }
318
319  /**
320   * Sets a custom {@code Equivalence} strategy for comparing keys.
321   *
322   * <p>By default, the cache uses {@link Equivalence#identity} to determine key equality when
323   * {@link #weakKeys} is specified, and {@link Equivalence#equals()} otherwise.
324   *
325   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
326   */
327  @GwtIncompatible // To be supported
328  CacheBuilder<K, V> keyEquivalence(Equivalence<Object> equivalence) {
329    checkState(keyEquivalence == null, "key equivalence was already set to %s", keyEquivalence);
330    keyEquivalence = checkNotNull(equivalence);
331    return this;
332  }
333
334  Equivalence<Object> getKeyEquivalence() {
335    return MoreObjects.firstNonNull(keyEquivalence, getKeyStrength().defaultEquivalence());
336  }
337
338  /**
339   * Sets a custom {@code Equivalence} strategy for comparing values.
340   *
341   * <p>By default, the cache uses {@link Equivalence#identity} to determine value equality when
342   * {@link #weakValues} or {@link #softValues} is specified, and {@link Equivalence#equals()}
343   * otherwise.
344   *
345   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
346   */
347  @GwtIncompatible // To be supported
348  CacheBuilder<K, V> valueEquivalence(Equivalence<Object> equivalence) {
349    checkState(
350        valueEquivalence == null, "value equivalence was already set to %s", valueEquivalence);
351    this.valueEquivalence = checkNotNull(equivalence);
352    return this;
353  }
354
355  Equivalence<Object> getValueEquivalence() {
356    return MoreObjects.firstNonNull(valueEquivalence, getValueStrength().defaultEquivalence());
357  }
358
359  /**
360   * Sets the minimum total size for the internal hash tables. For example, if the initial capacity
361   * is {@code 60}, and the concurrency level is {@code 8}, then eight segments are created, each
362   * having a hash table of size eight. Providing a large enough estimate at construction time
363   * avoids the need for expensive resizing operations later, but setting this value unnecessarily
364   * high wastes memory.
365   *
366   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
367   * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code initialCapacity} is negative
368   * @throws IllegalStateException if an initial capacity was already set
369   */
370  public CacheBuilder<K, V> initialCapacity(int initialCapacity) {
371    checkState(
372        this.initialCapacity == UNSET_INT,
373        "initial capacity was already set to %s",
374        this.initialCapacity);
375    checkArgument(initialCapacity >= 0);
376    this.initialCapacity = initialCapacity;
377    return this;
378  }
379
380  int getInitialCapacity() {
381    return (initialCapacity == UNSET_INT) ? DEFAULT_INITIAL_CAPACITY : initialCapacity;
382  }
383
384  /**
385   * Guides the allowed concurrency among update operations. Used as a hint for internal sizing. The
386   * table is internally partitioned to try to permit the indicated number of concurrent updates
387   * without contention. Because assignment of entries to these partitions is not necessarily
388   * uniform, the actual concurrency observed may vary. Ideally, you should choose a value to
389   * accommodate as many threads as will ever concurrently modify the table. Using a significantly
390   * higher value than you need can waste space and time, and a significantly lower value can lead
391   * to thread contention. But overestimates and underestimates within an order of magnitude do not
392   * usually have much noticeable impact. A value of one permits only one thread to modify the cache
393   * at a time, but since read operations and cache loading computations can proceed concurrently,
394   * this still yields higher concurrency than full synchronization.
395   *
396   * <p>Defaults to 4. <b>Note:</b>The default may change in the future. If you care about this
397   * value, you should always choose it explicitly.
398   *
399   * <p>The current implementation uses the concurrency level to create a fixed number of hashtable
400   * segments, each governed by its own write lock. The segment lock is taken once for each explicit
401   * write, and twice for each cache loading computation (once prior to loading the new value, and
402   * once after loading completes). Much internal cache management is performed at the segment
403   * granularity. For example, access queues and write queues are kept per segment when they are
404   * required by the selected eviction algorithm. As such, when writing unit tests it is not
405   * uncommon to specify {@code concurrencyLevel(1)} in order to achieve more deterministic eviction
406   * behavior.
407   *
408   * <p>Note that future implementations may abandon segment locking in favor of more advanced
409   * concurrency controls.
410   *
411   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
412   * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code concurrencyLevel} is nonpositive
413   * @throws IllegalStateException if a concurrency level was already set
414   */
415  public CacheBuilder<K, V> concurrencyLevel(int concurrencyLevel) {
416    checkState(
417        this.concurrencyLevel == UNSET_INT,
418        "concurrency level was already set to %s",
419        this.concurrencyLevel);
420    checkArgument(concurrencyLevel > 0);
421    this.concurrencyLevel = concurrencyLevel;
422    return this;
423  }
424
425  int getConcurrencyLevel() {
426    return (concurrencyLevel == UNSET_INT) ? DEFAULT_CONCURRENCY_LEVEL : concurrencyLevel;
427  }
428
429  /**
430   * Specifies the maximum number of entries the cache may contain.
431   *
432   * <p>Note that the cache <b>may evict an entry before this limit is exceeded</b>. For example, in
433   * the current implementation, when {@code concurrencyLevel} is greater than {@code 1}, each
434   * resulting segment inside the cache <i>independently</i> limits its own size to approximately
435   * {@code maximumSize / concurrencyLevel}.
436   *
437   * <p>When eviction is necessary, the cache evicts entries that are less likely to be used again.
438   * For example, the cache may evict an entry because it hasn't been used recently or very often.
439   *
440   * <p>If {@code maximumSize} is zero, elements will be evicted immediately after being loaded into
441   * cache. This can be useful in testing, or to disable caching temporarily.
442   *
443   * <p>This feature cannot be used in conjunction with {@link #maximumWeight}.
444   *
445   * @param maximumSize the maximum size of the cache
446   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
447   * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code maximumSize} is negative
448   * @throws IllegalStateException if a maximum size or weight was already set
449   */
450  public CacheBuilder<K, V> maximumSize(long maximumSize) {
451    checkState(
452        this.maximumSize == UNSET_INT, "maximum size was already set to %s", this.maximumSize);
453    checkState(
454        this.maximumWeight == UNSET_INT,
455        "maximum weight was already set to %s",
456        this.maximumWeight);
457    checkState(this.weigher == null, "maximum size can not be combined with weigher");
458    checkArgument(maximumSize >= 0, "maximum size must not be negative");
459    this.maximumSize = maximumSize;
460    return this;
461  }
462
463  /**
464   * Specifies the maximum weight of entries the cache may contain. Weight is determined using the
465   * {@link Weigher} specified with {@link #weigher}, and use of this method requires a
466   * corresponding call to {@link #weigher} prior to calling {@link #build}.
467   *
468   * <p>Note that the cache <b>may evict an entry before this limit is exceeded</b>. For example, in
469   * the current implementation, when {@code concurrencyLevel} is greater than {@code 1}, each
470   * resulting segment inside the cache <i>independently</i> limits its own weight to approximately
471   * {@code maximumWeight / concurrencyLevel}.
472   *
473   * <p>When eviction is necessary, the cache evicts entries that are less likely to be used again.
474   * For example, the cache may evict an entry because it hasn't been used recently or very often.
475   *
476   * <p>If {@code maximumWeight} is zero, elements will be evicted immediately after being loaded
477   * into cache. This can be useful in testing, or to disable caching temporarily.
478   *
479   * <p>Note that weight is only used to determine whether the cache is over capacity; it has no
480   * effect on selecting which entry should be evicted next.
481   *
482   * <p>This feature cannot be used in conjunction with {@link #maximumSize}.
483   *
484   * @param maximumWeight the maximum total weight of entries the cache may contain
485   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
486   * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code maximumWeight} is negative
487   * @throws IllegalStateException if a maximum weight or size was already set
488   * @since 11.0
489   */
490  @GwtIncompatible // To be supported
491  public CacheBuilder<K, V> maximumWeight(long maximumWeight) {
492    checkState(
493        this.maximumWeight == UNSET_INT,
494        "maximum weight was already set to %s",
495        this.maximumWeight);
496    checkState(
497        this.maximumSize == UNSET_INT, "maximum size was already set to %s", this.maximumSize);
498    checkArgument(maximumWeight >= 0, "maximum weight must not be negative");
499    this.maximumWeight = maximumWeight;
500    return this;
501  }
502
503  /**
504   * Specifies the weigher to use in determining the weight of entries. Entry weight is taken into
505   * consideration by {@link #maximumWeight(long)} when determining which entries to evict, and use
506   * of this method requires a corresponding call to {@link #maximumWeight(long)} prior to calling
507   * {@link #build}. Weights are measured and recorded when entries are inserted into the cache, and
508   * are thus effectively static during the lifetime of a cache entry.
509   *
510   * <p>When the weight of an entry is zero it will not be considered for size-based eviction
511   * (though it still may be evicted by other means).
512   *
513   * <p><b>Important note:</b> Instead of returning <em>this</em> as a {@code CacheBuilder}
514   * instance, this method returns {@code CacheBuilder<K1, V1>}. From this point on, either the
515   * original reference or the returned reference may be used to complete configuration and build
516   * the cache, but only the "generic" one is type-safe. That is, it will properly prevent you from
517   * building caches whose key or value types are incompatible with the types accepted by the
518   * weigher already provided; the {@code CacheBuilder} type cannot do this. For best results,
519   * simply use the standard method-chaining idiom, as illustrated in the documentation at top,
520   * configuring a {@code CacheBuilder} and building your {@link Cache} all in a single statement.
521   *
522   * <p><b>Warning:</b> if you ignore the above advice, and use this {@code CacheBuilder} to build a
523   * cache whose key or value type is incompatible with the weigher, you will likely experience a
524   * {@link ClassCastException} at some <i>undefined</i> point in the future.
525   *
526   * @param weigher the weigher to use in calculating the weight of cache entries
527   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
528   * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code size} is negative
529   * @throws IllegalStateException if a maximum size was already set
530   * @since 11.0
531   */
532  @GwtIncompatible // To be supported
533  public <K1 extends K, V1 extends V> CacheBuilder<K1, V1> weigher(
534      Weigher<? super K1, ? super V1> weigher) {
535    checkState(this.weigher == null);
536    if (strictParsing) {
537      checkState(
538          this.maximumSize == UNSET_INT,
539          "weigher can not be combined with maximum size",
540          this.maximumSize);
541    }
542
543    // safely limiting the kinds of caches this can produce
544    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
545    CacheBuilder<K1, V1> me = (CacheBuilder<K1, V1>) this;
546    me.weigher = checkNotNull(weigher);
547    return me;
548  }
549
550  long getMaximumWeight() {
551    if (expireAfterWriteNanos == 0 || expireAfterAccessNanos == 0) {
552      return 0;
553    }
554    return (weigher == null) ? maximumSize : maximumWeight;
555  }
556
557  // Make a safe contravariant cast now so we don't have to do it over and over.
558  @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
559  <K1 extends K, V1 extends V> Weigher<K1, V1> getWeigher() {
560    return (Weigher<K1, V1>) MoreObjects.firstNonNull(weigher, OneWeigher.INSTANCE);
561  }
562
563  /**
564   * Specifies that each key (not value) stored in the cache should be wrapped in a {@link
565   * WeakReference} (by default, strong references are used).
566   *
567   * <p><b>Warning:</b> when this method is used, the resulting cache will use identity ({@code ==})
568   * comparison to determine equality of keys. Its {@link Cache#asMap} view will therefore
569   * technically violate the {@link Map} specification (in the same way that {@link IdentityHashMap}
570   * does).
571   *
572   * <p>Entries with keys that have been garbage collected may be counted in {@link Cache#size}, but
573   * will never be visible to read or write operations; such entries are cleaned up as part of the
574   * routine maintenance described in the class javadoc.
575   *
576   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
577   * @throws IllegalStateException if the key strength was already set
578   */
579  @GwtIncompatible // java.lang.ref.WeakReference
580  public CacheBuilder<K, V> weakKeys() {
581    return setKeyStrength(Strength.WEAK);
582  }
583
584  CacheBuilder<K, V> setKeyStrength(Strength strength) {
585    checkState(keyStrength == null, "Key strength was already set to %s", keyStrength);
586    keyStrength = checkNotNull(strength);
587    return this;
588  }
589
590  Strength getKeyStrength() {
591    return MoreObjects.firstNonNull(keyStrength, Strength.STRONG);
592  }
593
594  /**
595   * Specifies that each value (not key) stored in the cache should be wrapped in a {@link
596   * WeakReference} (by default, strong references are used).
597   *
598   * <p>Weak values will be garbage collected once they are weakly reachable. This makes them a poor
599   * candidate for caching; consider {@link #softValues} instead.
600   *
601   * <p><b>Note:</b> when this method is used, the resulting cache will use identity ({@code ==})
602   * comparison to determine equality of values.
603   *
604   * <p>Entries with values that have been garbage collected may be counted in {@link Cache#size},
605   * but will never be visible to read or write operations; such entries are cleaned up as part of
606   * the routine maintenance described in the class javadoc.
607   *
608   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
609   * @throws IllegalStateException if the value strength was already set
610   */
611  @GwtIncompatible // java.lang.ref.WeakReference
612  public CacheBuilder<K, V> weakValues() {
613    return setValueStrength(Strength.WEAK);
614  }
615
616  /**
617   * Specifies that each value (not key) stored in the cache should be wrapped in a {@link
618   * SoftReference} (by default, strong references are used). Softly-referenced objects will be
619   * garbage-collected in a <i>globally</i> least-recently-used manner, in response to memory
620   * demand.
621   *
622   * <p><b>Warning:</b> in most circumstances it is better to set a per-cache {@linkplain
623   * #maximumSize(long) maximum size} instead of using soft references. You should only use this
624   * method if you are well familiar with the practical consequences of soft references.
625   *
626   * <p><b>Note:</b> when this method is used, the resulting cache will use identity ({@code ==})
627   * comparison to determine equality of values.
628   *
629   * <p>Entries with values that have been garbage collected may be counted in {@link Cache#size},
630   * but will never be visible to read or write operations; such entries are cleaned up as part of
631   * the routine maintenance described in the class javadoc.
632   *
633   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
634   * @throws IllegalStateException if the value strength was already set
635   */
636  @GwtIncompatible // java.lang.ref.SoftReference
637  public CacheBuilder<K, V> softValues() {
638    return setValueStrength(Strength.SOFT);
639  }
640
641  CacheBuilder<K, V> setValueStrength(Strength strength) {
642    checkState(valueStrength == null, "Value strength was already set to %s", valueStrength);
643    valueStrength = checkNotNull(strength);
644    return this;
645  }
646
647  Strength getValueStrength() {
648    return MoreObjects.firstNonNull(valueStrength, Strength.STRONG);
649  }
650
651  /**
652   * Specifies that each entry should be automatically removed from the cache once a fixed duration
653   * has elapsed after the entry's creation, or the most recent replacement of its value.
654   *
655   * <p>When {@code duration} is zero, this method hands off to {@link #maximumSize(long)
656   * maximumSize}{@code (0)}, ignoring any otherwise-specified maximum size or weight. This can be
657   * useful in testing, or to disable caching temporarily without a code change.
658   *
659   * <p>Expired entries may be counted in {@link Cache#size}, but will never be visible to read or
660   * write operations. Expired entries are cleaned up as part of the routine maintenance described
661   * in the class javadoc.
662   *
663   * @param duration the length of time after an entry is created that it should be automatically
664   *     removed
665   * @param unit the unit that {@code duration} is expressed in
666   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
667   * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code duration} is negative
668   * @throws IllegalStateException if {@link #expireAfterWrite} was already set
669   */
670  @SuppressWarnings("GoodTime") // should accept a java.time.Duration
671  public CacheBuilder<K, V> expireAfterWrite(long duration, TimeUnit unit) {
672    checkState(
673        expireAfterWriteNanos == UNSET_INT,
674        "expireAfterWrite was already set to %s ns",
675        expireAfterWriteNanos);
676    checkArgument(duration >= 0, "duration cannot be negative: %s %s", duration, unit);
677    this.expireAfterWriteNanos = unit.toNanos(duration);
678    return this;
679  }
680
681  @SuppressWarnings("GoodTime") // nanos internally, should be Duration
682  long getExpireAfterWriteNanos() {
683    return (expireAfterWriteNanos == UNSET_INT) ? DEFAULT_EXPIRATION_NANOS : expireAfterWriteNanos;
684  }
685
686  /**
687   * Specifies that each entry should be automatically removed from the cache once a fixed duration
688   * has elapsed after the entry's creation, the most recent replacement of its value, or its last
689   * access. Access time is reset by all cache read and write operations (including {@code
690   * Cache.asMap().get(Object)} and {@code Cache.asMap().put(K, V)}), but not by {@code
691   * containsKey(Object)}, nor by operations on the collection-views of {@link Cache#asMap}. So, for
692   * example, iterating through {@code Cache.asMap().entrySet()} does not reset access time for the
693   * entries you retrieve.
694   *
695   * <p>When {@code duration} is zero, this method hands off to {@link #maximumSize(long)
696   * maximumSize}{@code (0)}, ignoring any otherwise-specified maximum size or weight. This can be
697   * useful in testing, or to disable caching temporarily without a code change.
698   *
699   * <p>Expired entries may be counted in {@link Cache#size}, but will never be visible to read or
700   * write operations. Expired entries are cleaned up as part of the routine maintenance described
701   * in the class javadoc.
702   *
703   * @param duration the length of time after an entry is last accessed that it should be
704   *     automatically removed
705   * @param unit the unit that {@code duration} is expressed in
706   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
707   * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code duration} is negative
708   * @throws IllegalStateException if {@link #expireAfterAccess} was already set
709   */
710  @SuppressWarnings("GoodTime") // should accept a java.time.Duration
711  public CacheBuilder<K, V> expireAfterAccess(long duration, TimeUnit unit) {
712    checkState(
713        expireAfterAccessNanos == UNSET_INT,
714        "expireAfterAccess was already set to %s ns",
715        expireAfterAccessNanos);
716    checkArgument(duration >= 0, "duration cannot be negative: %s %s", duration, unit);
717    this.expireAfterAccessNanos = unit.toNanos(duration);
718    return this;
719  }
720
721  @SuppressWarnings("GoodTime") // nanos internally, should be Duration
722  long getExpireAfterAccessNanos() {
723    return (expireAfterAccessNanos == UNSET_INT)
724        ? DEFAULT_EXPIRATION_NANOS
725        : expireAfterAccessNanos;
726  }
727
728  /**
729   * Specifies that active entries are eligible for automatic refresh once a fixed duration has
730   * elapsed after the entry's creation, or the most recent replacement of its value. The semantics
731   * of refreshes are specified in {@link LoadingCache#refresh}, and are performed by calling {@link
732   * CacheLoader#reload}.
733   *
734   * <p>As the default implementation of {@link CacheLoader#reload} is synchronous, it is
735   * recommended that users of this method override {@link CacheLoader#reload} with an asynchronous
736   * implementation; otherwise refreshes will be performed during unrelated cache read and write
737   * operations.
738   *
739   * <p>Currently automatic refreshes are performed when the first stale request for an entry
740   * occurs. The request triggering refresh will make a blocking call to {@link CacheLoader#reload}
741   * and immediately return the new value if the returned future is complete, and the old value
742   * otherwise.
743   *
744   * <p><b>Note:</b> <i>all exceptions thrown during refresh will be logged and then swallowed</i>.
745   *
746   * @param duration the length of time after an entry is created that it should be considered
747   *     stale, and thus eligible for refresh
748   * @param unit the unit that {@code duration} is expressed in
749   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
750   * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code duration} is negative
751   * @throws IllegalStateException if {@link #refreshAfterWrite} was already set
752   * @since 11.0
753   */
754  @GwtIncompatible // To be supported (synchronously).
755  @SuppressWarnings("GoodTime") // should accept a java.time.Duration
756  public CacheBuilder<K, V> refreshAfterWrite(long duration, TimeUnit unit) {
757    checkNotNull(unit);
758    checkState(refreshNanos == UNSET_INT, "refresh was already set to %s ns", refreshNanos);
759    checkArgument(duration > 0, "duration must be positive: %s %s", duration, unit);
760    this.refreshNanos = unit.toNanos(duration);
761    return this;
762  }
763
764  @SuppressWarnings("GoodTime") // nanos internally, should be Duration
765  long getRefreshNanos() {
766    return (refreshNanos == UNSET_INT) ? DEFAULT_REFRESH_NANOS : refreshNanos;
767  }
768
769  /**
770   * Specifies a nanosecond-precision time source for this cache. By default, {@link
771   * System#nanoTime} is used.
772   *
773   * <p>The primary intent of this method is to facilitate testing of caches with a fake or mock
774   * time source.
775   *
776   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
777   * @throws IllegalStateException if a ticker was already set
778   */
779  public CacheBuilder<K, V> ticker(Ticker ticker) {
780    checkState(this.ticker == null);
781    this.ticker = checkNotNull(ticker);
782    return this;
783  }
784
785  Ticker getTicker(boolean recordsTime) {
786    if (ticker != null) {
787      return ticker;
788    }
789    return recordsTime ? Ticker.systemTicker() : NULL_TICKER;
790  }
791
792  /**
793   * Specifies a listener instance that caches should notify each time an entry is removed for any
794   * {@linkplain RemovalCause reason}. Each cache created by this builder will invoke this listener
795   * as part of the routine maintenance described in the class documentation above.
796   *
797   * <p><b>Warning:</b> after invoking this method, do not continue to use <i>this</i> cache builder
798   * reference; instead use the reference this method <i>returns</i>. At runtime, these point to the
799   * same instance, but only the returned reference has the correct generic type information so as
800   * to ensure type safety. For best results, use the standard method-chaining idiom illustrated in
801   * the class documentation above, configuring a builder and building your cache in a single
802   * statement. Failure to heed this advice can result in a {@link ClassCastException} being thrown
803   * by a cache operation at some <i>undefined</i> point in the future.
804   *
805   * <p><b>Warning:</b> any exception thrown by {@code listener} will <i>not</i> be propagated to
806   * the {@code Cache} user, only logged via a {@link Logger}.
807   *
808   * @return the cache builder reference that should be used instead of {@code this} for any
809   *     remaining configuration and cache building
810   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
811   * @throws IllegalStateException if a removal listener was already set
812   */
813  @CheckReturnValue
814  public <K1 extends K, V1 extends V> CacheBuilder<K1, V1> removalListener(
815      RemovalListener<? super K1, ? super V1> listener) {
816    checkState(this.removalListener == null);
817
818    // safely limiting the kinds of caches this can produce
819    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
820    CacheBuilder<K1, V1> me = (CacheBuilder<K1, V1>) this;
821    me.removalListener = checkNotNull(listener);
822    return me;
823  }
824
825  // Make a safe contravariant cast now so we don't have to do it over and over.
826  @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
827  <K1 extends K, V1 extends V> RemovalListener<K1, V1> getRemovalListener() {
828    return (RemovalListener<K1, V1>)
829        MoreObjects.firstNonNull(removalListener, NullListener.INSTANCE);
830  }
831
832  /**
833   * Enable the accumulation of {@link CacheStats} during the operation of the cache. Without this
834   * {@link Cache#stats} will return zero for all statistics. Note that recording stats requires
835   * bookkeeping to be performed with each operation, and thus imposes a performance penalty on
836   * cache operation.
837   *
838   * @return this {@code CacheBuilder} instance (for chaining)
839   * @since 12.0 (previously, stats collection was automatic)
840   */
841  public CacheBuilder<K, V> recordStats() {
842    statsCounterSupplier = CACHE_STATS_COUNTER;
843    return this;
844  }
845
846  boolean isRecordingStats() {
847    return statsCounterSupplier == CACHE_STATS_COUNTER;
848  }
849
850  Supplier<? extends StatsCounter> getStatsCounterSupplier() {
851    return statsCounterSupplier;
852  }
853
854  /**
855   * Builds a cache, which either returns an already-loaded value for a given key or atomically
856   * computes or retrieves it using the supplied {@code CacheLoader}. If another thread is currently
857   * loading the value for this key, simply waits for that thread to finish and returns its loaded
858   * value. Note that multiple threads can concurrently load values for distinct keys.
859   *
860   * <p>This method does not alter the state of this {@code CacheBuilder} instance, so it can be
861   * invoked again to create multiple independent caches.
862   *
863   * @param loader the cache loader used to obtain new values
864   * @return a cache having the requested features
865   */
866  @CheckReturnValue
867  public <K1 extends K, V1 extends V> LoadingCache<K1, V1> build(
868      CacheLoader<? super K1, V1> loader) {
869    checkWeightWithWeigher();
870    return new LocalCache.LocalLoadingCache<>(this, loader);
871  }
872
873  /**
874   * Builds a cache which does not automatically load values when keys are requested.
875   *
876   * <p>Consider {@link #build(CacheLoader)} instead, if it is feasible to implement a {@code
877   * CacheLoader}.
878   *
879   * <p>This method does not alter the state of this {@code CacheBuilder} instance, so it can be
880   * invoked again to create multiple independent caches.
881   *
882   * @return a cache having the requested features
883   * @since 11.0
884   */
885  @CheckReturnValue
886  public <K1 extends K, V1 extends V> Cache<K1, V1> build() {
887    checkWeightWithWeigher();
888    checkNonLoadingCache();
889    return new LocalCache.LocalManualCache<>(this);
890  }
891
892  private void checkNonLoadingCache() {
893    checkState(refreshNanos == UNSET_INT, "refreshAfterWrite requires a LoadingCache");
894  }
895
896  private void checkWeightWithWeigher() {
897    if (weigher == null) {
898      checkState(maximumWeight == UNSET_INT, "maximumWeight requires weigher");
899    } else {
900      if (strictParsing) {
901        checkState(maximumWeight != UNSET_INT, "weigher requires maximumWeight");
902      } else {
903        if (maximumWeight == UNSET_INT) {
904          logger.log(Level.WARNING, "ignoring weigher specified without maximumWeight");
905        }
906      }
907    }
908  }
909
910  /**
911   * Returns a string representation for this CacheBuilder instance. The exact form of the returned
912   * string is not specified.
913   */
914  @Override
915  public String toString() {
916    MoreObjects.ToStringHelper s = MoreObjects.toStringHelper(this);
917    if (initialCapacity != UNSET_INT) {
918      s.add("initialCapacity", initialCapacity);
919    }
920    if (concurrencyLevel != UNSET_INT) {
921      s.add("concurrencyLevel", concurrencyLevel);
922    }
923    if (maximumSize != UNSET_INT) {
924      s.add("maximumSize", maximumSize);
925    }
926    if (maximumWeight != UNSET_INT) {
927      s.add("maximumWeight", maximumWeight);
928    }
929    if (expireAfterWriteNanos != UNSET_INT) {
930      s.add("expireAfterWrite", expireAfterWriteNanos + "ns");
931    }
932    if (expireAfterAccessNanos != UNSET_INT) {
933      s.add("expireAfterAccess", expireAfterAccessNanos + "ns");
934    }
935    if (keyStrength != null) {
936      s.add("keyStrength", Ascii.toLowerCase(keyStrength.toString()));
937    }
938    if (valueStrength != null) {
939      s.add("valueStrength", Ascii.toLowerCase(valueStrength.toString()));
940    }
941    if (keyEquivalence != null) {
942      s.addValue("keyEquivalence");
943    }
944    if (valueEquivalence != null) {
945      s.addValue("valueEquivalence");
946    }
947    if (removalListener != null) {
948      s.addValue("removalListener");
949    }
950    return s.toString();
951  }
952}
